repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
**Problem:** #30313 introduced a change to `vim.treesitter.get_parser` that would always show a deprecation warning message without giving plugins/users a way to suppress it by updating to the new functionality.

**Solution:** Introduce `opts.error` to allow plugins/users to explicitly say that they are moving away from the deprecated functionality, thus allowing them to remove the annoying warning. See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30313#issuecomment-2349327458

comment_data.body: a way to give ourselves a reminder about this in the future is to add a `test/functional/lua/deprecated_spec.lua` file with an `it()` test case that checks `vim.version.ge(vim.version(), '0.11')`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -113,18 +113,26 @@ end
 ---
 --- If needed, this will create the parser.
 ---
+--- NOTE: This function will return `nil` rather than throwing an error in
+--- Nvim 0.12. Please pass `opts.error = false` to achieve this behavior

comment_data.body: I think there is no merit in having `_get_parser()` anymore, so maybe resolve this TODO here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -113,18 +113,26 @@ end
 ---
 --- If needed, this will create the parser.
 ---
+--- NOTE: This function will return `nil` rather than throwing an error in
+--- Nvim 0.12. Please pass `opts.error = false` to achieve this behavior
+--- now.
+---
 ---@param bufnr (integer|nil) Buffer the parser should be tied to (default: current buffer)
 ---@param lang (string|nil) Language of this parser (default: from buffer filetype)
 ---@param opts (table|nil) Options to pass to the created language tree
 ---
----@return vim.treesitter.LanguageTree object to use for parsing
+---@return vim.treesitter.LanguageTree? object to use for parsing
 function M.get_parser(bufnr, lang, opts)
   -- TODO(ribru17): Remove _get_parser and move that logic back here once the breaking function

comment_data.body:
I think this `vim.notify()` also suffers from the similar issue as `vim.notify_once()` in the `get_parser()`.

Prior to #30313 the call `local has_ts = pcall(vim.treesitter.start, 0)` could be used to start tree-sitter in the buffer while falling back to something else in case of `has_ts == false`. Now it does not fail silently and there is no good way of suppressing the notification. Possible solutions may be:
- Suggest to first call `vim.treesitter.get_parser` to check if there is a parser for the buffer and possibly fall back to something else. This leads to essentially calling `get_parser` twice if there *is a parser, which is not ideal.
- Show no notification if there is no parser (i.e. fail silently).

Not sure what is the best approach here. I'd probably choose a silent fail here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -438,7 +446,7 @@ end
 ---@param lang (string|nil) Language of the parser (default: from buffer filetype)
 function M.start(bufnr, lang)
   bufnr = bufnr or api.nvim_get_current_buf()
-  local parser = M._get_parser(bufnr, lang)
+  local parser = M.get_parser(bufnr, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     vim.notify('No parser for the given buffer.', vim.log.levels.WARN)

comment_data.body:
> I think this vim.notify() also suffers from the similar issue as vim.notify_once() in the get_parser().

Yes, but `start` is something that _users_ call (possibly interactively), so they expect feedback -- and `vim.notify` is what we have for this. Let's keep focused on the low-level `get_parser` function.

-  local ts_parser = vim.treesitter._get_parser()
+  local ts_parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(nil, nil, { error = false })

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- If no parser can be created, an error is thrown. Set `opts.error = false` to suppress this and return nil instead.
--- WARNING: This behavior will become default in Nvim 0.12 and the option will be removed.
```

This was changed in #30313, so I thought it is reasonable to be discussed here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -438,7 +446,7 @@ end
 ---@param lang (string|nil) Language of the parser (default: from buffer filetype)
 function M.start(bufnr, lang)
   bufnr = bufnr or api.nvim_get_current_buf()
-  local parser = M._get_parser(bufnr, lang)
+  local parser = M.get_parser(bufnr, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     vim.notify('No parser for the given buffer.', vim.log.levels.WARN)

comment_data.body:
Yes, but correctly so. _That_ is where the warning _should_ be triggered (at top of the stack).

Otherwise this sounds like a fundamental (unresolvable) problem with `vim.notify`: that callers cannot silence it by `pcall` (which is deliberate since we use it for deprecation warnings that should be handled instead of ignored).

What you are correct about is that the API is missing a clear `has_parser` function; hence my comment about refactoring `vim.treesitter.language.add` so that it returns a value (instead of throwing an error) that can be used for that purpose. (This was something that was lost in the `require_language` deprecation.)

comment_data.body: But maybe I am wrong, and throwing errors and catching them (and the error message) with `pcall` is really the correct way of such "exception handling"? In this case, we should simply revert.

comment_data.body:
Careful; user != caller (that would be a plugin). The point here is that we need to be careful with deprecations that concern plugins. In particular, we should absolutely minimize the chance that the warning will trigger a "press ENTER" prompt.

Personally, I would consider a soft deprecation here (doc change only).

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -438,7 +446,7 @@ end
 ---@param lang (string|nil) Language of the parser (default: from buffer filetype)
 function M.start(bufnr, lang)
   bufnr = bufnr or api.nvim_get_current_buf()
-  local parser = M._get_parser(bufnr, lang)
+  local parser = M.get_parser(bufnr, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     vim.notify('No parser for the given buffer.', vim.log.levels.WARN)

comment_data.body:
There's two issues here:
1. Signaling to the _calling function_ that a parser couldn't be found.
2. Signaling to the _user_ that a parser couldn't be found.

A change in 1. would be considered breaking (code), but a change in 2. would _not_. So no user-facing warning here should be added. If we want to prevent breaking code, we will _have to_ throw an `error`; if we don't, we simply document this and brace for impact.

TL;DR: Error or error not; there is no `vim.notifiy`.

comment_data.body: No, I mean use `assert` _here_ with the more informative error message. It's equivalent, of course; it's just a question of which pattern we want to promote (`if not foo then error('bar')` vs. `assert(foo, 'bar')`).

comment_data.body: The option becoming default and the option being removed should happen in separate releases. Might want to reword here to clarify that. “This behavior will become default in Nvim 0.12 and removed in a future release”
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -818,6 +818,10 @@ get_parser({bufnr}, {lang}, {opts})              *vim.treesitter.get_parser()*
 
     If needed, this will create the parser.
 
+    If no parser can be created, an error is thrown. Set `opts.error = false`
+    to suppress this and return nil instead. WARNING: This behavior will
+    become default in Nvim 0.12 and the option will be removed.

comment_data.body:
No, the proposal is in fact for an expedited deprecation (flying under the "experimental" flag). If there are _specific_ objections to that (and the related API change; this is a bigger project), I would like to hear them. (This change is _much_ easier to adapt to than the query iteration one.)

I would like to minimize the amount of breakage but not drag it out.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -818,6 +818,10 @@ get_parser({bufnr}, {lang}, {opts})              *vim.treesitter.get_parser()*
 
     If needed, this will create the parser.
 
+    If no parser can be created, an error is thrown. Set `opts.error = false`
+    to suppress this and return nil instead. WARNING: This behavior will
+    become default in Nvim 0.12 and the option will be removed.

comment_data.body: To be more precise: What I'm looking for here is scenarios where the option removal will be breaking whereas the default switch would not be. (Note that you're opting in to the new behavior, not the old one, from the start -- unlike the query change.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -818,6 +818,10 @@ get_parser({bufnr}, {lang}, {opts})              *vim.treesitter.get_parser()*
 
     If needed, this will create the parser.
 
+    If no parser can be created, an error is thrown. Set `opts.error = false`
+    to suppress this and return nil instead. WARNING: This behavior will
+    become default in Nvim 0.12 and the option will be removed.

comment_data.body:
Sorry to "one more thing" you, but I think the error message should contain as much context as possible -- in this case also the language name. (This may be called from "distros", so the context may not be always clear to the user.)

(This is related to a regression on treesitter highlight error messages, which used to contain the language and query name.)

And I am actually not at all fond of propagating error messages as strings. Either
1. `assert` them,
2. notify them, or 
3. log them,

but keep them where they happen.

comment_data.body:
> And I am actually not at all fond of propagating error messages as strings.

It's a standard Lua pattern. The error should be asserted/notified at the application level (`:InspectTree` in this case, or other plugin code), not the "library"/API level.

comment_data.body: Yes, and pcall is the standard approach for that pattern (throw/catch), isn't it?

+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(bufnr or 0, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer.'
   end

comment_data.body:
Sorry, I'm not making my point very well; let me try again. It's not about the error itself, it's about the message -- in particular, where it is constructed. I believe that this should be as close as possible to the point where the actual error is raised.

In this case, you're asking a function "do this thing", to which it replies "I cannot do this thing you ask". Now, we have just established a convention for that: simply return `nil`, which tells the calling function all it needs to know. Why should we return an additional string that says exactly the same thing, just in (more) words? What is that message telling the calling function that it cannot infer from the `nil` return, and what does it do with this information? Why can't `:InspectTree` not simply do `assert(parser, 'No parser available for the buffer')`?

(Or put differently: Hard-coded error strings without dynamic content are sus.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -76,7 +76,7 @@ end
 ---
 ---@package
 function TSTreeView:new(bufnr, lang)
-  local parser = vim.treesitter._get_parser(bufnr or 0, lang)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(bufnr or 0, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer.'
   end

comment_data.body: Concretely, my proposal is 'do not return an error message here, `nil` already means "No parser available", just return'.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -595,7 +595,7 @@ function M.edit_query(lang)
   end
   vim.cmd(cmd)
 
-  local parser = vim.treesitter._get_parser(buf, lang)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer'
   end

comment_data.body:
How else will the caller know why the function failed? Maybe there is only a single error path now, but there could be more in the future, and in that case we would want to explain what the error was. 

Returning an error message also lets callers simply use `local blah = assert(vim.treesitter.dev.show_tree())` which will conveniently show the error message “for free” (this is the same pattern Lua itself uses in e.g. the `io` library. I don’t see any reason to deviate here).

+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf, lang, { error = false })

   end

comment_data.body: Then that error message should provide more value, if it's the (only) one that is surfaced to the user. (At the very least, _which_ parser? _which_ buffer?)

comment_data.body:
Also, I'm a bit confused, since we're commenting here on `:EditQuery`, which does not have a "caller" (in the sense of a calling function -- unless we are talking about the `nvim_create_usercommand`, which then needs to `assert` the call).

Sorry for being so ornery, but I'm genuinely interested in having a discussion about this so I can understand the _full_ pattern across our API (at least treesitter, possibly beyond). Ideally, we'll get something we can actually write in `develop.txt` and I can follow in future PRs instead of winging it based on contributor style as we (certainly I) have so far.

(Part of the concern is that adding the error message to the return value locks the return part of the API. If we want to promote this pattern, we'll have to standardize on `retval, err`, with `retval` being a table for forward compatibility. Of course, that's very restrictive...)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -595,7 +595,7 @@ function M.edit_query(lang)
   end
   vim.cmd(cmd)
 
-  local parser = vim.treesitter._get_parser(buf, lang)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer'
   end

comment_data.body:
>Also, I'm a bit confused, since we're commenting here on :EditQuery, which does not have a "caller" (in the sense of a calling function -- unless we are talking about the nvim_create_usercommand, which then needs to assert the call).

No, we're talking about `vim.treesitter.dev.edit_query()`, which does have a caller.

>If we want to promote this pattern, we'll have to standardize on retval, err, with retval being a table for forward compatibility. 

This is a good point, and I hadn't appreciated until this comment that the API in question (`edit_query`) does not return a value.

IMO for functions which are only called for their side effects (like this one), calling `assert` or `error` directly is appropriate (I realize that takes this entire discussion in a different direction, I apologize for not looking closer at this earlier).

The pattern of returning `retval, err` is the right one to use for functions which return a value (like `TSTreeView::new`).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -595,7 +595,7 @@ function M.edit_query(lang)
   end
   vim.cmd(cmd)
 
-  local parser = vim.treesitter._get_parser(buf, lang)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer'
   end

comment_data.body:
Thank you, that helps in wrapping my mind around this. It's clear that "one size fits all" fits none, so my goal is to understand (with the help of these examples) which pattern is appropriate in which situation; and the difference between "generators" (that return a value) and "actors" (that don't, and are called purely for their side effects) is one I tried making earlier.

What muddies the waters here unfortunately is that some of the functions change their type in these PRs...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -595,7 +595,7 @@ function M.edit_query(lang)
   end
   vim.cmd(cmd)
 
-  local parser = vim.treesitter._get_parser(buf, lang)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer'
   end

comment_data.body:
>  but I'm genuinely interested in having a discussion about this so I can understand the full pattern across our API (at least treesitter, possibly beyond). Ideally, we'll get something we can actually write in develop.txt and I can follow in future PRs instead of winging it based on contributor style as we (certainly I) have so far.

> (Part of the concern is that adding the error message to the return value locks the return part of the API. If we want to promote this pattern, we'll have to standardize on retval, err, with retval being a table for forward compatibility. Of course, that's very restrictive...)


I think part of the challenge here is that:

- there's no clear established pattern (yet)
- it's not one size fit all
- different contributors have slightly different preferences

From what I can tell we have at least:

1. `error("no luck")`
2. `retval, errmsg`
3. optional result, no errormsg
4. `on_error` parameter (async, visitors - where `n` errors can happen)
5. `vim.notify` (sometimes with optional `opts.silent` (async, visitors ^))


My personal reasoning for when to use which (so far):


1) is well suited for cases where the error is very exceptional, in a lower level and where the consumers are unlikely to handle it in a meaningful way. Advantage over 2) is that propagation happens for free and it's harder to accidentally swallow errors. (E.g. using `uv_handle/pipe:write()` without checking return values is common)

2) is well suited for cases where the error is more likely or where having a fallback is more realistic. This is also more suited than 1) to have a list of well known error codes which could be returned as a third value. For scenarios where the user may be able to handle a few specific cases in different ways.

3) Kinda same as 2. where there is only a single case of "doesn't exist" (e.g. cache lookup, dict lookup)

4) lower level, either async methods or where the error can happen multiple times

5) Higher level. End-user invokes these directly

@@ -595,7 +595,7 @@ function M.edit_query(lang)
   end
   vim.cmd(cmd)
 
-  local parser = vim.treesitter._get_parser(buf, lang)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer'
   end

comment_data.body:
Thank you, that is exactly the sort of guidance I was hoping for (and puts a proper face on my vague and confusing thoughts)!

To complement this from the other side, what would be guidelines for using `pcall` /  `assert`? (Eating vs propagating vs. throwing errors).

(This is basically already suitable for copy&pasting into `develop.txt` under "Error handling". I would then only add a reminder on making sure to use `string.format` to include _all relevant_ context in the error message -- that is basically free in the non-error case if done correctly (how), right?)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -595,7 +595,7 @@ function M.edit_query(lang)
   end
   vim.cmd(cmd)
 
-  local parser = vim.treesitter._get_parser(buf, lang)
+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer'
   end

comment_data.body:
> what would be guidelines for using pcall / assert? (Eating vs propagating vs. throwing errors).

I'd say:

`pcall` only if you either:

- rethrow and enrich the error with additional context
- can provide a fallback, or in case of a higher level function want to avoid the user getting a error with stacktrace but only a warning

`assert` is either:

- defensive programming: To make an assumption explicit that should always be true due to contracts.
- alternative to `error` ⬇️

In regards to `assert(truthy, msg)` vs. `if condition then error(msg) end`:
Use the latter if building the `msg` would be costly (and do it only within the if block. Otherwise `assert` is fine.


(Disclaimer: This is just how I've been using these things, not sure if there's consensus on these)

+  local parser = vim.treesitter.get_parser(buf, lang, { error = false })
   if not parser then
     return nil, 'No parser available for the given buffer'
   end

comment_data.body:
Ah, that's a good point: `assert` needs a constructed message (which I believe should be the default ;))

And I would absolutely find these helpful in our docs as "things to consider". (Or, "So you want to throw an error.")

comment_regular_data.body:
@ribru17 I think the query linter may be broken by the change as well? (Sorry, don't have the time to bisect right now; just wanted to note this down somewhere.) Looks like `language.inspect()` fails now?

But #30379 seems to fix it again :)
I tried and it seems to work for me, both with this change and just with the previous `get_parser` change

> ... is there any reason you switched from calling the private function in our code (which is exactly what it's for ;)) to calling the public function with explicit option in this PR? ...

I think it was a reaction to [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30382#discussion_r1759985116) which *did* suggest not creating `_get_parser()` as it is mostly obsolete. I guess it is a miscommunication over the followed "Yes, that todo is obsolete now.".

> > ... is there any reason you switched from calling the private function in our code (which is exactly what it's for ;)) to calling the public function with explicit option in this PR? ...
> 
> I think it was a reaction to [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30382#discussion_r1759985116) which _did_ suggest not creating `_get_parser()` as it is mostly obsolete. I guess it is a miscommunication over the followed "Yes, that todo is obsolete now.".

Ah, ok, I missed that `_get_parser` is gone completely (change view was confusing...)

That's fine, but since we don't have a standard deprecation warning, we should probably still have a `todo` about removing the option -- or is the documentation warning enough?

> That's fine, but since we don't have a standard deprecation warning, we should probably still have a `todo` about removing the option -- or is the documentation warning enough?

I added a test indicating the option should be removed in 0.12, maybe that + the documentation warning is enough?
